name: Bobby L. Rush

Trayvon Martin was an innocent Black boy killed because of George Zimmerman's racist assumptions, racial resentment, and anger.

We will never forget him. And we will never stop fighting for a world where all children have the chance to grow up. #RestInPower

name: Bobby L. Rush

He was 17, walking back from a convenience store with iced tea and candy.

He had committed no crime, posed no threat.

He was shot dead by a neighborhood watch volunteer who said he looked "suspicious."

"Suspicious" because #TrayvonMartin was Black and he was wearing a hoodie. https://t.co/0QWLygPg0P

After 120 years and nearly 200 attempts, this bill will make lynching a federal hate crime and send a resounding message that we are finally reckoning with our history and committed to changing course.

name: Bobby L. Rush

When Derek Chauvin kneeled on George Floyd's neck for nine minutes, killing him, three of his fellow police officers were watching.

They did not intervene.
They kept bystanders away.
They did not provide medical care to #GeorgeFloyd when he lost his pulse.

Yes, they are guilty.

name: Bobby L. Rush

name: Bobby L. Rush

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text:
I am also praying for Chicago’s vibrant Ukrainian community and for their loved ones in Europe who may be impacted by this war.

Ukraine must know that the American people and the American government stand unequivocally with them during this time of crisis.

name: Bobby L. Rush

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text:
The window in my office is directly across from the Capitol. So, I watched the mob run up the Capitol steps. I saw the buses that had brought the marauding insurrectionists there. I saw the police officers.

It was a very, very eerie feeling. We were stunned, alarmed, and afraid.

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text:
At the time, we thought the Capitol might be the safest place to go. But, only Members were allowed in because of COVID precautions.

I told the two staffers with me that day, “I’m not leaving without you.” So, we hunkered down. We bolted and barricaded the door. And we waited.

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text:
On #January6th, I was in my office in Rayburn when we heard the news that insurrectionists had breached one of the buildings in the Capitol complex.

My staff and I turned to each other and started thinking frantically about what to do — what was our plan? [THREAD]

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text: The exclusion of hot and prepared foods under #SNAP is misguided and harms individuals who may be experiencing homelessness, recovering from a natural disaster, or otherwise lack convenient access to a kitchen — in other words, people among those most in need.

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text:
The fact that you can use SNAP to purchase a frozen, breaded chicken, but not a hot rotisserie chicken, frankly, makes no sense.

I'm proud to introduce the SNAP PLUS Act today with @RepGraceMeng & @RepBrianFitz to fix this disparity and allow #SNAP to cover hot & prepared foods.

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text:
Growing up, my family was always on the edge financially. I remember many times when I would not have a decent meal for dinner.

Food security is personal to me, as it is to the more than 40 million Americans who rely on #SNAP to help feed themselves and their families.

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text:
More than 6,500 Black Americans were lynched between 1865 and 1950.

Today, despite nearly 200 attempts over the past 120 years to pass antilynching legislation, lynching is STILL not a federal crime. My Emmett Till #AntilynchingAct would change that.

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text:
I was 8 years old when my mother put the photo of Emmett Till’s brutalized body in Jet Magazine on our coffee table, pointed to it, and said, "this is why I brought my boys out of Georgia."

That photograph shaped my consciousness as a Black man and changed the course of my life.

name: Bobby L. Rush

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text: The police immediately opened fire, killing Fred as he lay in his bed next to his pregnant girlfriend. Our fellow Black Panther Party Member, Mark Clark, was also killed in the raid. My own apartment was raided the very next morning. https://t.co/DLuDPv0MeJ

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text: In the early hours of December 4, 1969, the Chicago Police Department — working in conjunction with the @FBI and the Cook County State's Attorney — entered an apartment that 7 members of the Black Panther Party were staying in, with the premeditated aim of murdering Fred Hampton.

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text: The outrageously senseless killing of Adam Toledo shakes me to my core. Adam was 13 years old. His tragic death is a ringing indictment of our current system, the state of policing in America today, and the way minority communities are systemically underinvested in & left behind.

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text: 100 days ago, a Trump-inspired mob fueled by lies stormed the U.S. Capitol to obstruct democracy. There must be accountability.

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text: Communication with family & friends while incarcerated has been proven to reduce recidivism. The suspension of in-person visits and the early spread of COVID-19 in prisons has made the fight for #phonejustice all the more urgent. Let's get it done.

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text: Since prisoners are paid slave wages (if at all), phone costs are usually paid by the person they are calling. Racial disparities in incarceration mean these charges are disproportionally borne by Black family & community members, who have been hardest hit by pandemic job losses.

name: Bobby L. Rush
tweet_text:
ICYMI: This week I introduced my Martha Wright Prison Phone Justice Act (H.R. 2489). 

I've been fighting against exorbitant & unjust communication charges for incarcerated individuals for years, but the COVID-19 pandemic has made this issue more important than ever. [THREAD🧵]
